- Donahue v. Boston, 393 Mass. 1 (1984).raw_text: - Donahue v. Boston, 393 Mass. 1 (1984) — (negligence and duty principles)
- Donahue v. Boston, 393 Mass. 1 (1984).proposition: Plaintiff will rely on these and other authoritative decisions, statutory provisions, and governing principles of Massachusetts tort law concerning duty, breach, causation, foreseeability, and damages to prove negligence.
- Donahue v. Boston, 393 Mass. 1 (1984).case_name: Treasurer of Rowley v. Town of Rowley
- Donahue v. Boston, 393 Mass. 1 (1984).support_reasoning: This opinion concerns municipal law and the statutory/ministerial duties of a town treasurer regarding payment of warrants, not tort concepts like duty of care, breach, causation, foreseeability, or damages. It does not discuss or apply Massachusetts negligence principles, so it does not provide authority for the general tort-law proposition the plaintiff asserts. Using this case as support for negligence elements would be inaccurate and out of context.
- Donahue v. Boston, 393 Mass. 1 (1984).relevant_excerpt: We have already stated that a town treasurer’s powers under G. L. c. 41, § 35, “are largely ministerial.” … “If they have been properly presented for payment, it is generally the duty of the treasurer of a municipality to pay outstanding warrants, and it is no part of the duty of the treasurer to inquire into the legality of the consideration for which they were given” … A treasurer cannot be liable for making payments required by law….

- Camerota v. City of New Bedford, 374 M.raw_text: - Camerota v. City of New Bedford, 374 Mass. 271 (1978) — (duty and foreseeability)
- Camerota v. City of New Bedford, 374 M.proposition: Plaintiff will rely on these and other authoritative decisions, statutory provisions, and governing principles of Massachusetts tort law concerning duty, breach, causation, foreseeability, and damages to prove negligence.
- Camerota v. City of New Bedford, 374 M.case_name: Superintendent of Worcester State Hospital v. Hagberg
- Camerota v. City of New Bedford, 374 M.support_reasoning: The opinion in Camerota v. City of New Bedford does not concern substantive negligence concepts like duty, breach, causation, foreseeability, or damages. It addresses evidentiary standards and appellate/mootness issues in mental health commitment proceedings. Accordingly, it does not provide authoritative support for general Massachusetts tort-law principles the proposition references.
- Camerota v. City of New Bedford, 374 M.relevant_excerpt: Here it is common ground that there is a need for such a higher standard. The only controversy is between “clear and convincing proof” and “proof beyond a reasonable doubt.” … In view of “the generally similar function and effects” of G. L. c. 123 and G. L. c. 123A, we think the standard of proof beyond a reasonable doubt applies under both.

- Kelley v. LaForce, 364 Mass. 301 (1973.raw_text: - Kelley v. LaForce, 364 Mass. 301 (1973) — (proximate cause and foreseeability)
- Kelley v. LaForce, 364 Mass. 301 (1973.proposition: Plaintiff will rely on these and other authoritative decisions, statutory provisions, and governing principles of Massachusetts tort law concerning duty, breach, causation, foreseeability, and damages to prove negligence.
- Kelley v. LaForce, 364 Mass. 301 (1973.support_reasoning: This is a criminal homicide appeal focusing on evidentiary rulings (autopsy, photographs, hypothetical questions to an expert, reasonable‑doubt instruction). It does not analyze or articulate Massachusetts tort principles regarding duty, breach, causation, foreseeability, or damages, nor does it discuss proximate cause in the tort sense. Using this case as authority for general Massachusetts negligence and foreseeability standards is therefore inaccurate.
- Kelley v. LaForce, 364 Mass. 301 (1973.relevant_excerpt:
The defendant’s arguments on this appeal mostly concern the admission of items of evidence relating to the cause of the victim’s death. We deal with those arguments seriatim.

1. Dr. Curtis, the medical examiner, gave detailed testimony describing the results of the autopsy which he performed on the body of the victim. He also gave his opinion as to the cause of death, based in part on the autopsy results... The lapse of time between death and the autopsy went to the weight to be given Dr. Curtis’s opinions, and not to their admissibility.

- Leeder v. New England Tel. & Tel. Co.,.raw_text: - Leeder v. New England Tel. & Tel. Co., 413 Mass. 266 (1992) — (liability for property damage)
- Leeder v. New England Tel. & Tel. Co.,.proposition: Plaintiff will rely on these and other authoritative decisions, statutory provisions, and governing principles of Massachusetts tort law concerning duty, breach, causation, foreseeability, and damages to prove negligence.
- Leeder v. New England Tel. & Tel. Co.,.case_name: Rushworth v. Registrar of Motor Vehicles
- Leeder v. New England Tel. & Tel. Co.,.support_reasoning: The case is a constitutional challenge to a statute mandating driver's license suspension for drug convictions and concerns due process, equal protection, and double jeopardy. It does not analyze or apply Massachusetts tort principles of duty, breach, causation, foreseeability, or damages, nor does it involve a negligence claim or property damage. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the tort-law proposition for which it is cited.
- Leeder v. New England Tel. & Tel. Co.,.relevant_excerpt: "At issue is the validity of G. L. c. 90, § 22 (f), which requires the Registrar of Motor Vehicles automatically to suspend the driver’s license or right to operate of a person convicted of violating G. L. c. 94C (1990 ed.), the Controlled Substances Act.... The plaintiffs challenge the statute on due process, equal protection, and double jeopardy grounds. We reject their challenges and direct the entry of a declaratory judgment upholding the statute against the challenges made."

- Gotsis v. Realty Co., 400 Mass. 604 (1.raw_text: - Gotsis v. Realty Co., 400 Mass. 604 (1987) — (duty to protect invitees/third parties)
- Gotsis v. Realty Co., 400 Mass. 604 (1.proposition: Plaintiff will rely on these and other authoritative decisions, statutory provisions, and governing principles of Massachusetts tort law concerning duty, breach, causation, foreseeability, and damages to prove negligence.
- Gotsis v. Realty Co., 400 Mass. 604 (1.support_reasoning: The excerpted opinion is a Massachusetts criminal case about the voluntariness and admissibility of a defendant’s statement and the adequacy of jury instructions on self-defense in a murder prosecution. It does not discuss civil negligence concepts such as duty, breach, causation, foreseeability, damages, or duties to protect invitees/third parties. Thus, it does not provide authority for the broad Massachusetts tort-law negligence principles for which it is cited.
- Gotsis v. Realty Co., 400 Mass. 604 (1.relevant_excerpt: The defendant’s second claim of error is that the judge failed to instruct the jury adequately with respect to self-defense as a defense to the charge of murder in the second degree. He also contends that the judge’s supplemental instructions in reply to the jury’s questions were erroneous because they failed to define self-defense. No objection was taken at trial. Therefore, we review the jury instructions for clear error creating a substantial risk of a miscarriage of justice.

- Slayton v. Massachusetts, 352 Mass. 22.raw_text: - Slayton v. Massachusetts, 352 Mass. 22 (1967) — (premises liability principles)
- Slayton v. Massachusetts, 352 Mass. 22.proposition: Plaintiff will rely on these and other authoritative decisions, statutory provisions, and governing principles of Massachusetts tort law concerning duty, breach, causation, foreseeability, and damages to prove negligence.
- Slayton v. Massachusetts, 352 Mass. 22.case_name: Metropolitan District Commission v. Department of Public Utilities
- Slayton v. Massachusetts, 352 Mass. 22.support_reasoning: This decision concerns public-utility ratemaking, the Department of Public Utilities’ authority, burdens of proof in rate-adjustment proceedings, and reparations for overcharges. It does not address premises liability or general Massachusetts tort doctrines of duty, breach, causation, foreseeability, or damages. Using it as authority for broad negligence principles in a premises-liability context is therefore inaccurate.
- Slayton v. Massachusetts, 352 Mass. 22.relevant_excerpt: “But that rule is only a part of the general rule regarding the burden of proof, namely, that the moving party must prove its case. Thus, where a reduction or other adjustment is sought in an existing rate… the party seeking the benefit of such an adjustment has the burden of proving that the existing rate should be changed.”

- Duffy v. Boston Elevated Railway Co.,.raw_text: - Duffy v. Boston Elevated Railway Co., 284 Mass. 115 (1933) — (breach and causation)
- Duffy v. Boston Elevated Railway Co.,.proposition: Plaintiff will rely on these and other authoritative decisions, statutory provisions, and governing principles of Massachusetts tort law concerning duty, breach, causation, foreseeability, and damages to prove negligence.
- Duffy v. Boston Elevated Railway Co.,.support_reasoning: The opinion applies core Massachusetts negligence principles of duty, breach, causation, and foreseeability to a backing driver injuring a young child, and discusses when parental negligence is or is not a proximate cause. It explains the heightened vigilance required when backing, the effect of the child’s incapacity for care, and how negligence of a custodian interacts with the defendant’s liability, thereby serving as authority on the cited tort concepts, particularly breach and causation.
- Duffy v. Boston Elevated Railway Co.,.relevant_excerpt: The backing of any vehicle entails more or less limitation on the view by the driver of the area to be traversed and thus requires corresponding vigilance on his part to avoid causing injury to persons who are known to be, or likely to be, there, whether the vehicle is being backed on a public street or on private land. … Although the evidence did not warrant the finding that the plaintiff had sustained the burden of proving that his parents exercised due care and even if it had affirmatively appeared that they did not exercise such care and were negligent in leaving him to play in the yard, the plaintiff would not be barred from recovery if such negligence were not the proximate cause of his injury.

- Salinger v. State St. Trust Co., 322 M.raw_text: - Salinger v. State St. Trust Co., 322 Mass. 110 (1947) — (standard of care)
- Salinger v. State St. Trust Co., 322 M.proposition: Plaintiff will rely on these and other authoritative decisions, statutory provisions, and governing principles of Massachusetts tort law concerning duty, breach, causation, foreseeability, and damages to prove negligence.
- Salinger v. State St. Trust Co., 322 M.case_name: Adiletto v. Brockton Cut Sole Corp.
- Salinger v. State St. Trust Co., 322 M.support_reasoning: The opinion is about exclusivity of the workers’ compensation remedy and whether the plaintiff’s injury arose out of and in the course of employment, based on pleadings admissions. It does not discuss or set out standards of care, duty, breach, causation, foreseeability, or damages in a negligence framework; instead it holds that the plaintiff’s sole remedy is under the workers’ compensation act. Citing this case as authority for general Massachusetts tort law principles of negligence is therefore inaccurate.
- Salinger v. State St. Trust Co., 322 M.relevant_excerpt: “In the case at bar the facts alleged in the declaration and admitted by the replication required a ruling that the injury to the plaintiff arose out of and in the course of her employment by the defendant… That the plaintiff had given no notice of reservation of her right of action at common law was expressly admitted by the replication. It follows that the plaintiff cannot maintain this action and must rely upon her remedies under the workmen’s compensation act.”

- McLaughlin v. Boston Edison Co., 423 M.raw_text: - McLaughlin v. Boston Edison Co., 423 Mass. 683 (1996) — (negligence causation and damages)
- McLaughlin v. Boston Edison Co., 423 M.proposition: Plaintiff will rely on these and other authoritative decisions, statutory provisions, and governing principles of Massachusetts tort law concerning duty, breach, causation, foreseeability, and damages to prove negligence.
- McLaughlin v. Boston Edison Co., 423 M.support_reasoning: This opinion is a Massachusetts trust reformation case focused on mistake and tax consequences, not a tort case about negligence, duty, breach, causation, foreseeability, or damages. It does not discuss or apply Massachusetts tort principles and therefore cannot be used as authority for the negligence-related proposition described. The proposition misattributes a tort-law function to a trusts-and-estates equity decision.
- McLaughlin v. Boston Edison Co., 423 M.relevant_excerpt: “The sole question on the merits is whether reformation of the trust is appropriate in the circumstances. We find that reformation of the trust by substituting the plaintiffs children for the nominee trust (which benefits the grandchildren) as beneficiaries of the QPR trust is justified by the doctrine of mistake.”

- Boston & Maine R.R. v. Allen, 372 Mass.raw_text: - Boston & Maine R.R. v. Allen, 372 Mass. 192 (1977) — (foreseeability and proximate cause)
- Boston & Maine R.R. v. Allen, 372 Mass.proposition: Plaintiff will rely on these and other authoritative decisions, statutory provisions, and governing principles of Massachusetts tort law concerning duty, breach, causation, foreseeability, and damages to prove negligence.
- Boston & Maine R.R. v. Allen, 372 Mass.support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal homicide appeal focused on sufficiency of evidence, jury instructions, evidentiary rulings, and alleged prosecutorial misconduct, not on civil tort concepts such as duty, breach, causation, foreseeability, or damages. It does not articulate or apply Massachusetts tort law principles of negligence. Therefore it does not provide authority for the broad negligence proposition for which it is cited.
- Boston & Maine R.R. v. Allen, 372 Mass.relevant_excerpt: Under our decisions there is no adequate basis for setting aside the jury’s verdict. See Commonwealth v. Gricus, 317 Mass. 403, 407 (1944). See also Commonwealth v. Britt, 358 Mass. 767, 770 (1971); Commonwealth v. French, 357 Mass. 356, 397-398 (1970), judgments vacated as to the death penalty sub nom. Limone v. Massachusetts, 408 U.S. 936 (1972).
